column2: I will live in the Past, the Present, and the Future! Scrooge repeated, as he scrambled out of bed.
column3: I will live in the Past, the Present, and the Future! Scrooge repeated, as he scrambled out of bed.

column2: They are not torn down, cried Scrooge, folding one of his bed-curtains in his arms, "they are not torn down, rings and all.
column3: They are not torn down, cried Scrooge, folding one of his bed curtains in his arms, "they are not torn down, rings and all.

column2: They are here--I am here--the shadows of the things that would have been, may be dispelled.
column3: They are here-I am here-the shadows of the things that would have been, may be dispelled.

column2: They will be.
column3: They will be.

column2: I don't know what to do! cried Scrooge, laughing and crying in the same breath; and making a perfect Laocooen of himself with his stockings.
column3: I don't know what to do! cried Scrooge, laughing and crying in the same breath; and making a perfect Laocooen of himself with his stockings.

column2: He had frisked into the sitting-room, and was now standing there: perfectly winded.
column3: He had frisked into the sitting room, and was now standing there: perfectly winded.

column2: There's the saucepan that the gruel was in! cried Scrooge, starting off again, and going round the fireplace. "There's the door, by which the Ghost of Jacob Marley entered!
column3: There's the saucepan that the gruel was in! cried Scrooge, starting off again, and going round the fireplace. "There's the door, by which the Ghost of Jacob Marley entered!

column2: There's the window where I saw the wandering Spirits!
column3: There's the window where I saw the wandering Spirits!

column2: Really, for a man who had been out of practice for so many years, it was a splendid laugh, a most illustrious laugh. The father of a long, long line of brilliant laughs!
column3: Really, for a man who had been out of practice for so many years, it was a splendid laugh, a most illustrious laugh. The father of a long, long line of brilliant laughs!

column2: I don't know anything.
column3: I don't know anything.

column2: I'm quite a baby.
column3: I'm quite a baby.

column2: Never mind.
column3: Never mind.

column2: I don't care.
column3: I don't care.

column2: He was checked in his transports by the churches ringing out the lustiest peals he had ever heard.
column3: He was checked in his transports by the churches ringing out the lustiest peals he had ever heard.

column2: Bell, dong, ding; hammer, clang, clash!
column3: Bell, dong, ding; hammer, clang, clash!

column2: Oh, glorious, glorious!
column3: Oh, glorious, glorious!

column2: No fog, no mist; clear, bright, jovial, stirring, cold; cold, piping for the blood to dance to; Golden sunlight; Heavenly sky; sweet fresh air; merry bells.
column3: No fog, no mist; clear, bright, jovial, stirring, cold; cold, piping for the blood to dance to; Golden sunlight; Heavenly sky; sweet fresh air; merry bells.

column2: Oh, glorious! Glorious!
column3: Oh, glorious! Glorious!

column2: What's to-day! cried Scrooge, calling downward to a boy in Sunday clothes, who perhaps had loitered in to look about him.
column3: What's to day! cried Scrooge, calling downward to a boy in Sunday clothes, who perhaps had loitered in to look about him.

column2: EH? returned the boy, with all his might of wonder.
column3: EH? returned the boy, with all his might of wonder.

column2: What's to-day, my fine fellow? said Scrooge.
column3: What's to day, my fine fellow? said Scrooge.

column2: To-day! replied the boy.
column3: To day! replied the boy.

column2: It's Christmas Day! said Scrooge to himself.
column3: It's Christmas Day! said Scrooge to himself.

column2: I haven't missed it.	I haven't missed it.
The Spirits have done it all in one night. They can do anything they like.
column3: The Spirits have done it all in one night. They can do anything they like.

column2: Of course they can.
column3: Of course they can.

column2: Hallo! returned the boy.
column3: Hallo! returned the boy.

column2: Do you know the Poulterer's, in the next street but one, at the corner? Scrooge inquired.
column3: Do you know the Poulterer's, in the next street but one, at the corner? Scrooge inquired.

column2: A remarkable boy! Do you know whether they've sold the prize Turkey that was hanging up there?--Not the little prize Turkey: the big one?
column3: A remarkable boy! Do you know whether they've sold the prize Turkey that was hanging up there?--Not the little prize Turkey: the big one?

column2: What, the one as big as me? returned the boy.
column3: What, the one as big as me? returned the boy.

column2: Yes, my buck!"
column3: Yes, my buck!"

column2: Is it? said Scrooge.
column3: Is it? said Scrooge.

column2: Go and buy it.
column3: Go and buy it.

column2: Walk-ER! exclaimed the boy.
column3: Walk ER! exclaimed the boy.

column2: No, no, said Scrooge, "I am in earnest.
column3: No, no, said Scrooge, "I am in earnest.

column2: Come back with the man, and I'll give you a shilling.
column3: Come back with the man, and I'll give you a shilling.

column2: Come back with him in less than five minutes and I'll give you half-a-crown!"
column3: Come back with him in less than five minutes and I'll give you half a crown!"

column2: The boy was off like a shot.
column3: The boy was off like a shot.

column2: He must have had a steady hand at a trigger who could have got a shot off half so fast.
column3: He must have had a steady hand at a trigger who could have got a shot off half so fast.

column2: I'll send it to Bob Cratchit's! whispered Scrooge, rubbing his hands, and splitting with a laugh.
column3: I'll send it to Bob Cratchit's! whispered Scrooge, rubbing his hands, and splitting with a laugh.

column2: The hand in which he wrote the address was not a steady one, but write it he did, somehow, and went down-stairs to open the street door, ready for the coming of the poulterer's man.
column3: The hand in which he wrote the address was not a steady one, but write it he did, somehow, and went down stairs to open the street door, ready for the coming of the poulterer's man.

column2: As he stood there, waiting his arrival, the knocker caught his eye.
column3: As he stood there, waiting his arrival, the knocker caught his eye.

column2: Whoop! How are you!
column3: Whoop! How are you!

column2: It was a Turkey!
column3: It was a Turkey!

column2: He never could have stood upon his legs, that bird.
column3: He never could have stood upon his legs, that bird.

column2: Why, it's impossible to carry that to Camden Town, said Scrooge.
column3: Why, it's impossible to carry that to Camden Town, said Scrooge.

column2: You must have a cab.
column3: You must have a cab.

column2: Shaving was not an easy task, for his hand continued to shake very much; and shaving requires attention, even when you don't dance while you are at it.
column3: Shaving was not an easy task, for his hand continued to shake very much; and shaving requires attention, even when you don't dance while you are at it.

column2: But if he had cut the end of his nose off, he would have put a piece of sticking-plaister over it, and been quite satisfied.
column3: But if he had cut the end of his nose off, he would have put a piece of sticking plaister over it, and been quite satisfied.

column2: He dressed himself "all in his best," and at last got out into the streets.
column3: He dressed himself "all in his best," and at last got out into the streets.

column2: The people were by this time pouring forth, as he had seen them with the Ghost of Christmas Present; and walking with his hands behind him, Scrooge regarded every one with a delighted smile.
column3: The people were by this time pouring forth, as he had seen them with the Ghost of Christmas Present; and walking with his hands behind him, Scrooge regarded every one with a delighted smile.

column2: He looked so irresistibly pleasant, in a word, that three or four good-humoured fellows said, "Good morning, sir!
column3: He looked so irresistibly pleasant, in a word, that three or four good humoured fellows said, "Good morning, sir!

column2: He had not gone far, when coming on towards him he beheld the portly gentleman, who had walked into his counting-house the day before, and said, "Scrooge and Marley's, I believe?"
column3: He had not gone far, when coming on towards him he beheld the portly gentleman, who had walked into his counting house the day before, and said, "Scrooge and Marley's, I believe?"

column2: It sent a pang across his heart to think how this old gentleman would look upon him when they met; but he knew what path lay straight before him, and he took it.
column3: It sent a pang across his heart to think how this old gentleman would look upon him when they met; but he knew what path lay straight before him, and he took it.

column2: My dear sir, said Scrooge, quickening his pace, and taking the old gentleman by both his hands.
column3: My dear sir, said Scrooge, quickening his pace, and taking the old gentleman by both his hands.

column2: How do you do?	How do you do?
I hope you succeeded yesterday.
column3: I hope you succeeded yesterday.

column2: A merry Christmas to you, sir!"
column3: A merry Christmas to you, sir!"

column2: Mr. Scrooge?
column3: mr Scrooge?

column2: Yes, said Scrooge.
column3: Yes, said Scrooge.

column2: Allow me to ask your pardon. And will you have the goodness"--here Scrooge whispered in his ear.
column3: Allow me to ask your pardon. And will you have the goodness"--here Scrooge whispered in his ear.

column2: Lord bless me! cried the gentleman, as if his breath were taken away.
column3: Lord bless me! cried the gentleman, as if his breath were taken away.

column2: My dear Mr. Scrooge, are you serious?
column3: My dear mr Scrooge, are you serious?

column2: If you please, said Scrooge.
column3: If you please, said Scrooge.

column2: Not a farthing less.	Not a farthing less.
A great many back-payments are included in it, I assure you. Will you do me that favour?"
column3: A great many back payments are included in it, I assure you. Will you do me that favour?"

column2: Don't say anything, please, retorted Scrooge.
column3: Don't say anything, please, retorted Scrooge.

column2: Come and see me.	Come and see me.
Will you come and see me?"
column3: Will you come and see me?"

column2: I will! cried the old gentleman.
column3: I will! cried the old gentleman.

column2: Bless you!"
column3: Bless you!"

column2: He had never dreamed that any walk--that anything--could give him so much happiness.
column3: He had never dreamed that any walk-that anything-could give him so much happiness.

column2: In the afternoon he turned his steps towards his nephew's house.
column3: In the afternoon he turned his steps towards his nephew's house.

column2: He passed the door a dozen times, before he had the courage to go up and knock.
column3: He passed the door a dozen times, before he had the courage to go up and knock.

column2: But he made a dash, and did it:
column3: But he made a dash, and did it:

column2: Nice girl!
column3: Nice girl!

column2: Very.
column3: Very.

column2: Yes, sir.
column3: Yes, sir.

column2: Where is he, my love? said Scrooge.
column3: Where is he, my love? said Scrooge.

column2: He's in the dining-room, sir, along with mistress.	He's in the dining room, sir, along with mistress.
I'll show you up-stairs, if you please."
column3: I'll show you up stairs, if you please."

column2: He knows me," said Scrooge, with his hand already on the dining-room lock.
column3: He knows me," said Scrooge, with his hand already on the dining room lock.

column2: I'll go in here, my dear.
column3: I'll go in here, my dear.

column2: He turned it gently, and sidled his face in, round the door. They were looking at the table (which was spread out in great array); for these young housekeepers are always nervous on such points, and like to see that everything is right.
column3: He turned it gently, and sidled his face in, round the door. They were looking at the table (which was spread out in great array); for these young housekeepers are always nervous on such points, and like to see that everything is right.

column2: Fred! said Scrooge.
column3: Fred! said Scrooge.

column2: It's I. Your uncle Scrooge.	It's i Your uncle Scrooge.
I have come to dinner. Will you let me in, Fred?"
column3: I have come to dinner. Will you let me in, Fred?"

column2: So did Topper when he came.
column3: So did Topper when he came.

column2: So did the plump sister when she came.
column3: So did the plump sister when she came.

column2: So did every one when they came.
column3: So did every one when they came.

column2: Wonderful party, wonderful games, wonderful unanimity, won-der-ful happiness!
column3: Wonderful party, wonderful games, wonderful unanimity, won der ful happiness!

column2: Oh, he was early there.
column3: Oh, he was early there.

column2: If he could only be there first, and catch Bob Cratchit coming late!
column3: If he could only be there first, and catch Bob Cratchit coming late!

column2: That was the thing he had set his heart upon.
column3: That was the thing he had set his heart upon.

column2: And he did it; yes, he did!
column3: And he did it; yes, he did!

column2: The clock struck nine.
column3: The clock struck nine.

column2: No Bob.
column3: No Bob.

column2: No Bob.
column3: No Bob.

column2: He was full eighteen minutes and a half behind his time.
column3: He was full eighteen minutes and a half behind his time.

column2: Scrooge sat with his door wide open, that he might see him come into the Tank.
column3: Scrooge sat with his door wide open, that he might see him come into the Tank.

column2: His hat was off, before he opened the door; his comforter too.
column3: His hat was off, before he opened the door; his comforter too.

column2: He was on his stool in a jiffy; driving away with his pen, as if he were trying to overtake nine o'clock.
column3: He was on his stool in a jiffy; driving away with his pen, as if he were trying to overtake nine o'clock.

column2: I am behind my time.
column3: I am behind my time.

column2: You are? repeated Scrooge.
column3: You are? repeated Scrooge.

column2: Yes.	Yes.
I think you are. Step this way, sir, if you please."
column3: I think you are. Step this way, sir, if you please."

column2: It's only once a year, sir, pleaded Bob, appearing from the Tank.
column3: It's only once a year, sir, pleaded Bob, appearing from the Tank.

column2: It shall not be repeated.	It shall not be repeated.
Now, I'll tell you what, my friend, said Scrooge, "I am not going to stand this sort of thing any longer.
column3: Now, I'll tell you what, my friend, said Scrooge, "I am not going to stand this sort of thing any longer.

column2: And therefore," he continued, leaping from his stool, and giving Bob such a dig in the waistcoat that he staggered back into the Tank again; "and therefore I am about to raise your salary!"
column3: And therefore," he continued, leaping from his stool, and giving Bob such a dig in the waistcoat that he staggered back into the Tank again; "and therefore I am about to raise your salary!"

column2: Bob trembled, and got a little nearer to the ruler.
column3: Bob trembled, and got a little nearer to the ruler.

column2: He had a momentary idea of knocking Scrooge down with it, holding him, and calling to the people in the court for help and a strait-waistcoat.
column3: He had a momentary idea of knocking Scrooge down with it, holding him, and calling to the people in the court for help and a strait waistcoat.

column2: A merry Christmas, Bob! said Scrooge, with an earnestness that could not be mistaken, as he clapped him on the back.
column3: A merry Christmas, Bob! said Scrooge, with an earnestness that could not be mistaken, as he clapped him on the back.

column2: A merrier Christmas, Bob, my good fellow, than I have given you, for many a year!	A merrier Christmas, Bob, my good fellow, than I have given you, for many a year!
Make up the fires, and buy another coal-scuttle before you dot another i, Bob Cratchit!"
column3: Make up the fires, and buy another coal scuttle before you dot another i, Bob Cratchit!"

column2: Scrooge was better than his word.

column2: He did it all, and infinitely more; and to Tiny Tim, who did NOT die, he was a second father.
column3: He did it all, and infinitely more; and to Tiny Tim, who did NOT die, he was a second father.

column2: He became as good a friend, as good a master, and as good a man, as the good old city knew, or any other good old city, town, or borough, in the good old world.
column3: He became as good a friend, as good a master, and as good a man, as the good old city knew, or any other good old city, town, or borough, in the good old world.

column2: His own heart laughed: and that was quite enough for him.
